name: Data Preparation and Workflow Management
description: Learn how to efficiently manage empirical research projects!

items.description: To follow this course and work on your team project later on, it is necessary to have installed the software, so make sure to complete this part right away!

items.name: Install R & RStudio
items.description: R & R Studio are the workhorses in this course - make sure to install them right away!

items.name: Install Git and make an account on GitHub
items.description: Git allows you to have an unlimited 'version history' - so you can always go back to any version of the file ever made. Get started now!

items.name: Install make
items.description: Make is like a robot, that runs your entire project from beginning to end! Sit back & relax, while you see your project come together!

items.name: Install VS Code
items.description: You need a good text editor for coding. Although much can be done in RStudio, it is sometimes useful to have a more powerful text editor available. So, install Visual Studio code now!

items.name: Verify that you have a premium account at Datacamp (i.e., mailed the library)
items.description: We use Datacamp in this class, but you need to go through a quite cumbersome onboarding procedure with the University library. Do this soon so you can enjoy premium content without having to pay for it!
Scrum is a very flexible way to work in teams, so get acquainted with it and use it with your project group later on!

items.name: Understand what the benefits are of using the scrum framework
items.description: Scrum is a very flexible way to work in teams, so get acquainted with it and use it with your project group later on!
This tutorial will introduce you to R and teach you the basic skills that you will use a lot when working with data

items.name: Know about data types in R (characteric, numeric, vector etc.)
items.description: Data types are used to constrain the values that an expression might take. You will use these a lot while programming!

items.name: Ability to load datasets in R and perform some data inspection tasks
items.description: These are generally the first things you do; loading the data and getting a glimpse of it

items.name: Know what a factor is and how to convert and rename these
items.description: Factors are variables which take on a certain number of different values

items.name: Understand what a pipeline (%>%) is in R and be able to work with these
items.description: Pipelines are a great way to combine multiple operations and simplify your code!

items.name: Know how to use data manipulation functions in dplyr, such as filter, group_by and mutate
items.description: These are common data manipulation tasks that you will use very often when analyzing data!

items.name: Know how to export data and write a cleaned dataset to a csv file
items.description: Once you have cleaned a dataset, you can store the cleaned datafile in a csv by using the write_csv function in R!

modules.name: Week 2
modules.description: Versioning projects with Git and GitHub!

items.name: Watch the energizer for this week
items.description: To get acquainted with this week's course material, watch the energizer!

items.name: Read the readings on managing your workflow and its importance on TilburgScienceHub
items.description: Managing your workflow is an important way to bring structure to your project and improve reproducability!

items.name: Read the optional reading on best practices for data projects
items.description: These optional readings will elaborate on the data analysis workflow and the version control of your project. Read through these to further improve your understanding of these concepts!

items.name: Read the optional reading on code and data for Social Sciences
items.description: These optional readings will elaborate on the data analysis workflow and the version control of your project. Read through these to further improve your understanding of these concepts!

items.name: Read the optional reading on data analysis workflow
items.description: These optional readings will elaborate on the data analysis workflow and the version control of your project. Read through these to further improve your understanding of these concepts!

items.name: Look through this paper to further familiarize yourself with this weekâ€™s content
items.description: These optional readings will elaborate on the data analysis workflow and the version control of your project. Read through these to further improve your understanding of these concepts!

items.name: Get an understanding of what the command line/terminal is by looking through the slides
items.description: These slides are especially beneficial for students that are using a Mac, but also gives you a good overall understanding of the command line and how we use it!

items.name: Complete the first chapter of the Introduction to Shell on Datacamp
items.description: Navigating through directories is a task you will often do when using Git Bash for example, so make sure to complete this tutorial!

items.name: Follow the short Github introduction on issues, pull requests and commits
items.description: This Github introduction will walk you through the basics of using Git and Github for your project!

items.name: Understand why we use Git over Google drive when working on code with others
items.description: Git is a very effective way to collaborate on projects with code. Do you understand the benefits of Git over Google Drive?

items.name: Create the version-control-exercises repository on Github and clone it
items.description: To get a repository from Github to your local computer, you will need to use git clone!

items.name: Understand the process of making changes to files and pushing these using Git (git add, commit etc.)
items.description: This is an iterative process that you will be performing often, so make sure you fully understand this!

items.name: Be able to clone a repository, make changes to this repository and then push these changes to Github
items.description: When you made changes on your local computer, you want this to be transferred to the main repository on Github. For that, we use git push!

items.name: Know how to find the history of a project and know how to roll back to a previous version of a project on Github using a hash
items.description: Everyone makes mistakes. Luckily, Git and Github allow you to easily roll back to previous versions of a project, should this be necessary

items.name: Understand what a gitignore file is used for and why this is used
items.description: You don't always want Git to track every file that you create or make a change to (take large csv files for example). Using gitignore, Git will stop tracking these files!

items.name: Know how to work on a branch of a project and the concept of merging branches with each other
items.description: Branches are ways to work on different parts of a project simultaneously with team members. These branches can be merged after being pushed

items.name: Know how to fork an existing repository of someone else
items.description: Forking allows you to propose changes to projects of others and is useful for open-source collaboration!
